Package com.satvik.args

Class Flag<T>

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.satvik.args.Flag<T>
  • Type Parameters:
    T - the type of value the Flag can hold - use a raw type if you need a normal Flag without a value

    public class Flag<T>
extends java.lang.Object
    This is the class describing a type of Flag which must be assigned a value. Flags are used extensively by classes in this package.

    In this method of interpreting flags, eaddch flag may have two synonimous forms : a 'short' form (-[charcacter]) and a long form (--[flag-name]), eg. a flag for 'help' may be represented by '-h' or '--help'. Flags have two states : on(true) and off(false) (off/false by default). Flags may also carry values with a '=' character immediately following either the long or short form, and preceding the actual value given to it, eg. '--max-val=20' will assign the string '20' to the flag represented by '--max-val'.

    If a Flag object is to carry a value, it must call the constructor Flag(String, String, Class<T>), and it's container variable must be of type Flag<T>, where T is the type of value the Flag can hold. An example of it's usage follows : 

     

 	.
 	.
 	.

	Flag help = new Flag("-h", "--help");		// Normal flag without value. Note that 
							// no value can be queried from it using 
							// flag.getValue() : attempting to 
							// do so throws a FlagException
	Flag<Integer> min = new Flag<>("-m", "--min", Integer.class);
							// This Flag may be assigned an Integer by 
							// ArgHandler while processing
	Flag<Integer> max = new Flag<>("-M", "--max", Integer.class, 10);
							// This Flag also has a default value of 10
	.
	.						// Create an ArgHandler and pass the Flags to it
	.
	
	Boolean needsHelp = help.getState();		// The state of the Flag can be retrieved 
							// by calling help.getState()
	Integer minVal = min.getValue();		// The value of min.getValue() can be stored 
							// directly in minVal, due to the use of generics
	Integer maxVal = max.getValue();		// If no value has been set, the default value
							// specified will be returned
	
	.
	.
	.

    Since:
    1.0
    Version:
    1.1, 04/05/2016
    Author:
    Satvik Saha
    See Also:
    ArgHandler

    • Constructor Detail

      • Flag

        public Flag(java.lang.String shortForm,
            java.lang.String longForm)
        This is the constructor of Flag which accepts the short and long forms of the Flag. The raw form of Flag must be used, as it is implied that the Flag cannot be assigned a value.
        Parameters:
        shortForm - the short form of the Flag
        longForm - the long form of the Flag
        Since:
        1.0

      • Flag

        public Flag(java.lang.String shortForm,
            java.lang.String longForm,
            java.lang.Class<T> valueTypeClass)
     throws FlagException
        This is the constructor of Flag which accepts the short and long forms of the Flag, as well as it's value type's class. The value type class must be one of the following : 
        
	Character.class
	String.class
	Byte.class
	Short.class
	Integer.class
	Long.class
	Float.class
	Double.class

        Any value type class other than the above will throw an InvalidFlagTypeException.
        Parameters:
        shortForm - the short form of the FlagWithValue
        longForm - the long form of the FlagWithValue
        valueTypeClass - the class of the type of value which can be assigned to the FlagWithValue
        Throws:
        FlagException - thrown if valueTypeClass does not belong to the list of accepted classes
        Since:
        1.0
        See Also:
        Flag(String, String)

      • Flag

        public Flag(java.lang.String shortForm,
            java.lang.String longForm,
            java.lang.Class<T> valueTypeClass,
            T defaultValue)
     throws FlagException
        This is the constructor of Flag which accepts the short and long forms of the Flag, as well as it's value type's class and a default value.
        Parameters:
        shortForm - the short form of the FlagWithValue
        longForm - the long form of the FlagWithValue
        valueTypeClass - the class of the type of value which can be assigned to the FlagWithValue
        defaultValue - the defaultValue assigned to the Flag
        Throws:
        FlagException - thrown if valueTypeClass does not belong to the list of accepted classes
        Since:
        1.0
        See Also:
        Flag(String, String, Class), Flag(String, String)

      • setParsedValue

        public void setParsedValue(java.lang.String rawValue)
                    throws FlagException
        This method sets the value of the Flag to the 'value type' form of rawValue. If rawValue cannot be converted to the value type of the Flag, an Exception is thrown.
        Parameters:
        rawValue - the raw String to be processed into an Object of class valueType
        Throws:
        FlagException - thrown if there is an error in prsing the raw String, or the Flag cannot carry value
        Since:
        1.0

      • getValue

        public T getValue()
           throws FlagException
        This method returns the value of the Flag, if set previously. If not, and Exception is thrown.
        Returns:
        the value stored in Flag
        Throws:
        FlagException - thrown if the Flag is empty, or cannot carry a value
        Since:
        1.0
